sanitised_text:
Situation: You're a politician running for office. A journalist asks you if you've ever used illegal drugs.

Person A: I can confidently say that I've spent my life trying to uphold the law, any youthful indiscretions were simply that, indiscretions. It's important to focus on the issues facing our community today.

expressions.text: I can confidently say that I've spent my life trying to uphold the law, any youthful indiscretions were simply that, indiscretions. It's important to focus on the issues facing our community today.

unused_labels: Acting as if nothing remarkable happened
Answering a different question than was asked
Choosing a most comfortable environment for themselves to feel more powerful
Convincing to give up something important
Creating a constraint favorable to the speaker
Giving too brief or incomplete answers
Making another person dependent on speaker for information
Making other feel like they are doing something wrong
Making others more dependent on them
Making others more dependent on them for information
Making others question their own reality
Making promises about great future while neglecting present situation
Not asking for the other person's viewpoint on relevant matters
Not verifying the negative assumptions about the other person
Reneging on commitments by deeming them superfluous
Reneging on commitments under the pretext of business interests being more important
Repeating a question that was already answered
Subverting the goals of the other person
qualitative_evaluation: Person A, presumably the politician, has a diplomatic and deflective conversational style. They avoid directly answering the question about illegal drug use, instead emphasizing their commitment to lawfulness and shifting the focus to current community issues. The journalist's style cannot be described as they do not speak in the provided text.
